    <TD>*&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The 2004 amount includes $1,091 of liabilities assumed in the
    acquisition of TMBR.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Had SFAS&nbsp;143 been in effect as of January&nbsp;1, 2001, the
impact on the Company&#146;s results of operations would have
been immaterial for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, and
the asset retirement obligation would have been
$1.1&nbsp;million and $1.0&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31,
2002 and 2001, respectively. In addition, the cumulative effect
of this change in accounting principle of approximately
$469,000, net of tax, was recorded in the first quarter of 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>9.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Notes&nbsp;Payable</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company replaced its prior credit facility in December 2004
with a five-year, $200&nbsp;million unsecured revolving line of
credit (&#147;LOC&#148;). Interest is to be paid on outstanding
LOC balances at a floating rate ranging from LIBOR plus 0.625%
to 1.0% or the prime rate. This arrangement includes various
fees, including a commitment fee on the average daily unused
amount (0.15% at December&nbsp;31, 2004). There are customary
restrictions and covenants associated with the LOC. Financial
covenants provide for a maximum debt to capitalization ratio and
a minimum interest coverage ratio. The Company does not expect
that the restrictions and covenants will restrict its ability to
operate or react to opportunities that might arise. Availability
under the LOC is reduced by outstanding letters of credit which
totaled $49&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004. There were
no outstanding borrowings under the LOC at December&nbsp;31,
2004. Costs of approximately $445,000 were expensed in 2004 to
terminate the previous $100&nbsp;million credit facility.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>10.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Commitments, Contingencies and Other Matters</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company maintains letters of credit in the aggregate amount
of $49.0&nbsp;million for the benefit of various insurance
companies as collateral for retrospective premiums and retained
losses which may become payable under the terms of the
underlying insurance contracts. These letters of credit expire
variously during each calendar year. No amounts have been drawn
under the letters of credit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Contingencies</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company&#146;s contract
services and oil and natural gas exploration and production
operations are subject to inherent risks, including blowouts,
cratering, fire and explosions which could result in personal
injury or death, suspended drilling operations, damage to, or
destruction of equipment, damage to producing formations and
pollution or other environmental hazards.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As a protection against these hazards, the Company maintains
general liability insurance coverage of $2.0&nbsp;million per
occurrence with $4.0&nbsp;million of aggregate coverage and
excess liability and umbrella
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-18

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
coverages up to $50.0&nbsp;million per occurrence and in the
aggregate. The Company maintains a $1.0&nbsp;million per
occurrence deductible on its workers&#146; compensation
insurance and its general liability insurance coverages. These
levels of self-insurance expose the Company to increased
operating costs and risks.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 includes a
charge of $4.7&nbsp;million related to the financial failure in
2002 of a workers&#146; compensation insurance carrier that had
provided coverage for the Company in prior years.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company believes it is adequately insured for public
liability and property damage to others with respect to its
operations. However, such insurance may not be sufficient to
protect the Company against liability for all consequences of
well disasters, extensive fire damage, or damage to the
environment. The Company also carries insurance to cover
physical damage to, or loss of, its rigs; however, it does not
carry insurance against loss of earnings resulting from such
damage or loss.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company is party to various legal proceedings arising in the
normal course of its business. The Company does not believe that
the outcome of these proceedings, either individually or in the
aggregate, will have a material adverse effect on its financial
condition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Other Matters</I>&nbsp;&#151; Effective January&nbsp;29,
2004, the Company entered into Change in Control Agreements with
its Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer, President
and Chief Operating Officer, two Senior Vice Presidents and
Chief Financial Officer (the &#147;Key Employees&#148;). Each
Change in Control Agreement generally has a three-year term with
automatic twelve month renewals unless the Company notifies the
Key Employee at least ninety days before the end of such renewal
period that the term will not be extended. If a change in
control of the Company occurs during the term of the agreement
and the Key Employee&#146;s employment is terminated (i)&nbsp;by
the Company other than for cause or other than automatically as
a result of death, disability or retirement or (ii)&nbsp;by the
Key Employee for good reason (as those terms are defined in the
Change in Control Agreements), then the Key Employee shall be
entitled to, among other things,
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    bonus payment equal to the greater of the highest bonus paid
    after the Change in Control Agreement was entered into and the
    average of the two annual bonuses earned in the two fiscal years
    immediately preceding a change in control (such bonus payment
    prorated for the portion of the fiscal year preceding the
    termination date);</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    a payment equal to 2.5 times (in the case of the Chairman of the
    Board, Chief Executive Officer and President and Chief Operating
    Officer) or 1.5 times (in the case of the Senior Vice Presidents
    and the Chief Financial Officer) of the sum of (i)&nbsp;the
    highest annual salary in effect for such Key Employee and
    (ii)&nbsp;the average of the three annual bonuses earned by the
    Key Employee for the three fiscal years preceding the
    termination date;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    continued coverage under the Company&#146;s welfare plans for up
    to three years (in the case of the Chairman of the Board, Chief
    Executive Officer and President and Chief Operating Officer) or
    two years (in the case of the Senior Vice Presidents and the
    Chief Financial Officer).</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Each Change in Control Agreement provides the Key Employee with
a full gross-up payment for any excise taxes imposed on payments
and benefits received under the Change in Control Agreements or
otherwise, including other taxes that may be imposed as a result
of the gross-up payment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>11.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stockholders&#146; Equity</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On June&nbsp;7, 2004, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors
authorized a stock buyback program for the purchase of up to
$30&nbsp;million of outstanding shares of the Company&#146;s
common stock. During the second quarter of 2004, the Company
purchased 100,000&nbsp;shares of its common stock in the open
market for approximately $1.5&nbsp;million (adjusted to reflect
the two-for-one stock split on June&nbsp;30, 2004). These shares
are included in treasury stock at December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-19

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During the second quarter of 2004, the Company granted
Restricted Shares to certain key employees under the
Patterson-UTI Energy, Inc. 1997 Long-Term Incentive Plan, as
amended. As required by APB&nbsp;25, the Restricted Shares were
valued based upon the market price of the Company&#146;s common
stock on the date of the grant. The resulting value is being
amortized over the vesting period of the stock. Compensation
expense of approximately $773,000, net of tax, was included in
net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On April&nbsp;28, 2004, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors
authorized a two-for-one stock split in the form of a stock
dividend which was distributed on June&nbsp;30, 2004 to holders
of record on June&nbsp;14, 2004. In connection with the
two-for-one stock split, an adjustment was made to reclassify an
amount from retained earnings to common stock to account for the
par value of the common stock issued as a stock dividend. This
adjustment had no overall effect on equity. The prior year
balance sheet was not restated as a result of this transaction;
however, historical earnings per share amounts included in the
Consolidated Statements of Income and elsewhere in this Report
have been restated as if the two-for-one stock split had
occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2002.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On April&nbsp;28, 2004, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors
approved the initiation of a quarterly cash dividend of $0.02 on
each share of its common stock which was paid on June&nbsp;2,
2004. Quarterly dividends in the amount of $0.02&nbsp;per share
were also paid on September&nbsp;1, 2004 and December&nbsp;1,
2004. Total dividends paid in 2004 were approximately
$10&nbsp;million. In February 2005, the Company&#146;s Board of
Directors approved an increase in the quarterly cash dividend on
the Company&#146;s common stock to $0.04 per share from $0.02
per share. The next quarterly cash dividend is to be paid to
holders of record on February&nbsp;28, 2005 and paid on
March&nbsp;4, 2005. The amount and timing of all future dividend
payments is subject to the discretion of the Board of Directors
and will depend upon business conditions, results of operations,
financial condition, terms of the Company&#146;s credit
facilities and other factors.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In February 2004, the Company completed its acquisition of TMBR
in which one of its wholly-owned subsidiaries acquired 100% of
the remaining outstanding shares of TMBR for a net cash payment
of $32.5&nbsp;million ($40.4&nbsp;million paid to TMBR
shareholders less $7.9&nbsp;million in cash acquired in the
transaction) and the issuance of 2.78&nbsp;million shares of the
Company&#146;s common stock valued at $17.82&nbsp;per share
(adjusted to reflect the two-for-one stock split on
June&nbsp;30, 2004). The assets of TMBR included
18&nbsp;land-based drilling rigs and related equipment, shop
facilities, equipment yards and their oil and natural gas
properties. The transaction was accounted for as a business
combination and the purchase price was allocated among the
assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their estimated
fair market values (see Note&nbsp;2).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During March 2002, the Company issued 1.3&nbsp;million shares
(adjusted to reflect the two-for-one stock split on
June&nbsp;30, 2004) of its common stock as consideration for the
acquisition of Odin Drilling, Inc. (see Note&nbsp;2). The common
stock was valued at $13.03&nbsp;per share, its fair market value
on the date the terms of the transaction were agreed upon.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-20

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Employee and Non-Employee Director Stock Option
Plans</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company has seven stock option plans
of which three have shares available for grant. The remaining
four plans are dormant and the Company does not intend to grant
any further options under such plans. At December&nbsp;31, 2004,
the Company&#146;s stock option plans were as follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Plan is for the benefit of employees of the Company, including
    officers and directors of the Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(2)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Plan is for the benefit of employees of the Company, other than
    officers and directors of the Company.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s active plans are the 1997 Plan, the 2001 Plan
and the Non-Employee Director Plan. A summary of each of these
plans is set forth below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>1997 Plan</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Administered by the Compensation Committee of the Board of
    Directors.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    All employees including officers and employee directors are
    eligible for awards.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Vesting schedule is set by the Compensation Committee, however,
    typically options vest over 3 or 5&nbsp;years.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The Compensation Committee sets the term of the option except
    that no Incentive Stock Option (&#147;ISO&#148;) can have a term
    of longer than 10&nbsp;years. Typically options granted under
    the plan have a term of 10&nbsp;years.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The options granted under the plan, unless otherwise stated in
    the grant thereof, vest upon a change of control as defined in
    the plan. Options granted to non-executive employees typically
    do not vest upon a change of control.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    All options granted under the plan are granted with an exercise
    price equal to or greater than the fair market value of the
    Company&#146;s common stock at the time the option is granted.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-21

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The plan allows for awards of tandem and independent stock
    appreciation rights, restricted stock and performance awards.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>2001 Plan</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The terms and conditions of the 2001 Plan are identical to the
1997 Plan except as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Officers and directors of the Company are not eligible for
    grants of options under the 2001 Plan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    No ISO&#146;s may be awarded under the 2001 Plan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Unless the grant states otherwise, options granted under the
    2001 Plan do not vest upon a change of control of the Company.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Non-Employee Director Plan</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Administered by the Compensation Committee of the Board of
    Directors.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    All options vest upon the first anniversary of the option grant.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Each director receives options to
    purchase&nbsp;40,000&nbsp;shares upon becoming a director of the
    Company and options to purchase&nbsp;20,000&nbsp;shares on
    December&nbsp;31st of each subsequent year in which the director
    serves as a director of the Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#149;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The exercise price of the options is the fair market value of
    the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>1995 Non-Employee Director Plan</I>&nbsp;&#151; Options
granted under the 1995 Non-Employee Director Plan vest on the
first anniversary of the option grant. 1995 Non-Employee
Director Plan options have five year terms. All options were
granted with an exercise price equal to the fair market value of
the Company&#146;s common stock at the time of grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>DSI Plan</I>&nbsp;&#151; The options granted under the DSI
plan typically vested at a rate of 33%&nbsp;per year with ten
year terms. All options were granted with an exercise price
equal to the fair market value of the Company&#146;s common
stock at the time of grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>1996 Plan</I>&nbsp;&#151; The options granted under the 1996
plan vested over one, four and five years as dictated by the
Compensation Committee. These options had terms of five and ten
years as dictated by the Compensation Committee. All options
were granted with an exercise price equal to the fair market
value of the Company&#146;s common stock at the time of grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>1993 Plan</I>&nbsp;&#151; Options granted under the 1993
Plan, typically had terms of 10&nbsp;years and vested over five
years in 20% increments beginning at the end of the first year.
These options vest in the event of a change of control as
defined in the plan. All options were granted with an exercise
price equal to the fair market value of the Company&#146;s
common stock at the time of grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Additional Options</I>&nbsp;&#151; In July 2001, the
Compensation Committee granted to each of two non-employee
directors of the Company an option to
purchase&nbsp;24,000&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common
stock. These options vested on November&nbsp;6, 2001 and
terminate on November&nbsp;5, 2005. The exercise price of each
of the options was $14.3125, which was in excess of the fair
market value of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of
grant.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-22

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Pro Forma Stock-Based Compensation Disclosure</I>&nbsp;&#151;
Pro forma information in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;123 regarding
net income and earnings per share, as described in Note&nbsp;1,
has been determined as if the Company had accounted for its
employee stock options under the fair value method as defined in
that statement. The fair value of each stock option granted is
estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option
valuation model with the following weighted-average assumptions
for grants in 1996 through 2004 respectively; dividend yield of
0.06% for all 2004 grants and 0.00% for all other grants;
risk-free interest rates are different for each grant and range
from 2.18% to 7.02%; the expected term ranges from 3 to
6&nbsp;years; and a volatility of 38.68% for all 1996 grants,
35.97% for all 1997 grants, 51.08% for all 1998 grants, 61.97%
for all 1999 grants, 67.71% for all 2000 grants, 68.33% for all
2001 grants, 63.02% for all 2002 grants, 44.04% for all 2003
grants and 36.84% for all 2004 grants. The effects of applying
SFAS&nbsp;123 in this pro forma disclosure are not indicative of
future amounts. SFAS&nbsp;123 does not apply to awards prior to
1996.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Stock Purchase Warrants</I>&nbsp;&#151; In December 2001, the
Company issued 650,000 warrants exercisable at $13.375&nbsp;per
share as partial consideration for the purchase of 17 drilling
rigs and related equipment from Cleere Drilling Company. The
warrants were fully exercisable at the date of issuance. All of
the warrants were exercised in December 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company incurred rent expense, consisting primarily of daily
rental charges for the use of drilling equipment, of
$9.1&nbsp;million, $8.6&nbsp;million and $5.7&nbsp;million, for
the years 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. The Company&#146;s
obligations under non-cancelable operating lease agreements are
not material to the Company&#146;s operations.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets,
management considers whether it is more likely than not that
some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be
realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is
dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during
the periods in which those temporary differences become
deductible. Management considers the scheduled reversal of
deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income and
tax planning strategies in making this assessment. The Company
expects the deferred tax assets at December&nbsp;31, 2004 to be
realized as a result of the reversal during the carryforward
period of existing taxable temporary differences giving rise to
deferred tax liabilities and the generation of taxable income in
the carryforward period; therefore, no valuation allowance is
necessary.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-25

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Other deferred tax assets consist primarily of various allowance
accounts and tax deferred expenses expected to generate future
tax benefit of approximately $7&nbsp;million. Other deferred tax
liabilities consist primarily of receivables from insurance
companies not yet recognized for tax purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For tax purposes, the Company has available at December&nbsp;31,
2004, Federal net operating loss carryforwards of approximately
$16&nbsp;million and $118,000 of alternative minimum tax credit
carryforwards. These carryforwards are attributable to the
acquisition of TMBR in February 2004.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-26
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The net operating loss carryforwards, if unused, are scheduled
to expire as follows: 2005&nbsp;&#151; $5&nbsp;million,
2006&nbsp;&#151; $1&nbsp;million, 2011&nbsp;&#151;
$2&nbsp;million, 2018&nbsp;&#151; $4&nbsp;million and
2019&nbsp;&#151; $4&nbsp;million. The alternative minimum tax
credit may be carried forward indefinitely.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>15.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Employee Benefits</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company maintains a 401(k) plan for all eligible employees.
The Company&#146;s operating results include expenses of
approximately $2.2&nbsp;million in 2004, $1.5&nbsp;million in
2003 and $2.1&nbsp;million in 2002 for the Company&#146;s
discretionary contributions to the plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>16.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Business Segments</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company conducts its business through four distinct
operating segments: contract drilling of oil and natural gas
wells, pressure pumping services and drilling and completion
fluids services to operators in the oil and natural gas
industry, and the exploration, development, acquisition and
production of oil and natural gas. Each of these segments
represents a distinct type of business based upon the type and
nature of services and products offered. These segments have
separate management teams which report to the Company&#146;s
chief executive officer and have distinct and identifiable
revenues and expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Contract Drilling</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company markets its
contract drilling services to major and independent oil and
natural gas operators. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company
owned 361 drilling rigs, of which 149 of the drilling rigs were
based in the Permian Basin region, 55 in South Texas, 42 in the
Ark-La-Tex region and Mississippi, 77 in the Mid-Continent
region, 21 in the Rocky Mountain region and 17 in Western
Canada. The Company operated 259 of its drilling rigs in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Pressure Pumping</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company provides
pressure pumping services primarily in the Appalachian Basin.
Pressure pumping services consist primarily of well stimulation
and cementing for the completion of new wells and remedial work
on existing wells. Well stimulation involves processes inside a
well designed to enhance the flow of oil, natural gas, or other
desired substances from the well. Cementing is the process of
inserting material between the hole and the pipe to center and
stabilize the pipe in the hole.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Drilling and Completion Fluids</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company
provides drilling fluids, completion fluids and related services
to oil and natural gas operators in Texas, Southeastern New
Mexico, Oklahoma, the Gulf Coast region of Louisiana and the
Gulf of Mexico. Drilling and completion fluids are used by oil
and natural gas operators during the drilling process to control
pressure when drilling oil and natural gas wells. The drilling
fluids operations were added by the Company during 1998 with its
acquisition of two companies with operations in Texas,
Southeastern New Mexico, Oklahoma and Colorado. The
Company&#146;s services were expanded to include completion
fluids in October 2000 with the acquisition of the drilling and
completion fluids division of Ambar, Inc., which had operations
in the coastal areas of Texas, Louisiana and in the Gulf of
Mexico.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Oil and Natural Gas</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company is engaged in
the development, exploration, acquisition and production of oil
and natural gas.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-27

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following tables summarize selected financial information
relating to the Company&#146;s business segments (in thousands):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="60%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(a)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes contract drilling intercompany revenues of
    approximately $6.0&nbsp;million, $1.1&nbsp;million and $457,000
    for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002,
    respectively.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(b)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes drilling and completion fluids intercompany revenues of
    approximately $301,000, $56,000 and $23,000 for the years ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(c)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Restructuring and other charges relate to decisions of the
    executive management group regarding corporate strategy, credit
    risk, loss contingencies and restructuring activities. Due to
    the non-operating nature of these decisions, the related charges
    have been separately presented and excluded from the results of
    specific segments. These charges are primarily related to the
    contract drilling segment.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>18.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Concentrations of Credit Risk</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Financial instruments, which potentially subject the Company to
concentrations of credit risk, consist primarily of demand
deposits, temporary cash investments and trade receivables.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">F-30

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company believes that it places its demand deposits and
temporary cash investments with high credit quality financial
institutions. At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the
Company&#146;s demand deposits and temporary cash investments
consisted of the following (in thousands):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="9"><FONT style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Concentrations of credit risk with respect to trade receivables
are primarily focused on companies involved in the exploration
and development of oil and natural gas properties. The
concentration is somewhat mitigated by the diversification of
customers for which the Company provides drilling services. As
is general industry practice, the Company generally does not
require customers to provide collateral. No significant losses
from individual contracts were experienced during the years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003, or 2002. The Company
recognized bad debt expense for 2004, 2003 and 2002 of $897,000,
$259,000 and $320,000, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents, marketable
securities and trade receivables approximate fair value due to
the short-term maturity of these assets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>19.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Related Party Transactions</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Joint Operation of Oil and Natural Gas
Properties</I>&nbsp;&#151; The Company operates certain oil and
natural gas properties in which certain of its affiliated
persons have participated, either individually or through
entities they control, in the prospects or properties in which
the Company has an interest. These participations, which have
been on a working interest basis, have been in prospects or
properties originated or acquired by Patterson-UTI. At
December&nbsp;31, 2004, affiliated persons were working interest
owners in 237 of 300 total wells operated by Patterson-UTI.
Sales were made by Patterson-UTI at its cost, comprised of
Patterson-UTI&#146;s costs of acquiring and preparing the
working interests for sale. These costs were paid by the working
interest owners on a pro rata basis based upon their working
interest ownership percentage. The price at which working
interests were sold to affiliated persons was the same price at
which working interests were sold to unaffiliated persons. The
affiliated persons earned oil and natural gas production revenue
(net of royalty) of $13.8&nbsp;million, $11.1&nbsp;million and
$6.9&nbsp;million from these properties in 2004, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. These persons or entities in turn paid for joint
operating costs (including drilling and other development
expenses) of $7.5&nbsp;million, $7.9&nbsp;million and
$5.5&nbsp;million incurred in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.
These activities resulted in a payable to the affiliated persons
of approximately $1.2&nbsp;million and $871,000 and a receivable
from the affiliated persons of approximately $856,000 and
$888,000 at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Other</I>&nbsp;&#151; In 2004, 2003 and 2002, the Company
paid approximately $914,000, $740,000 and $279,000,
respectively, to TMP Truck and Trailer LP (&#147;TMP&#148;), an
entity owned by Thomas M. Patterson (son of A. Glenn Patterson),
for certain equipment and metal fabrication services. Purchases
from TMP were at current market prices.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2004 and 2003, the Company paid approximately $39,000 and
$209,000, respectively, to Melco Services (&#147;Melco&#148;)
for dirt contracting services and $44,000 and $59,000,
respectively, to L&#38;N Transportation (&#147;L&#38;N&#148;)
for water hauling services. Both entities are owned by Lance D.
Nelson, brother of Jonathan D. Nelson, Patterson-UTI&#146;s
Chief Financial Officer. Purchases from Melco and L&#38;N were
at current market prices.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

respect to quantities of net proved oil and natural gas reserves

entirely within the United States.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Estimates of the Company&#146;s proved reserves and future net
revenues are determined based on various assumptions such as oil
and natural gas prices, operating costs, reservoir performance
and economic conditions. The oil and natural gas prices and
operating cost assumptions were based on the actual prices and
costs in effect as of the date of such estimates. These
assumptions are held constant throughout the life of the
properties, except operating costs are adjusted for contractual
escalations. The Company&#146;s independent petroleum engineer
estimates the assumptions relating to reservoir performance and
economic conditions using information available and industry
experience. The oil and natural gas prices used to value the
Company&#146;s reserves as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 were
$43.45&nbsp;per Bbl of oil and $6.15&nbsp;per Mcf of natural
gas. Estimates of reserves and production performance are
subjective and may change materially as actual production
information becomes available.
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ASSET PURCHASE AGREEMENT</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THIS ASSET PURCHASE AGREEMENT (this &#147;Agreement&#148;) is entered into as of December&nbsp;7, 2004, among
Key Energy Drilling, Inc., a Delaware corporation (&#147;Key Drilling&#148;), Key Energy Drilling Beneficial,
L.P., a Texas limited partnership (&#147;Key Drilling L.P.&#148;), Key Four Corners, Inc., a Delaware
corporation (&#147;Key Four Corners&#148;) and Key Rocky Mountain, Inc., a Delaware corporation (&#147;Key Rocky
Mountain&#148;, and together with Key Drilling, Key Four Corners and Key Rocky Mountain, the &#147;Sellers&#148;),
Key Energy Services, Inc., a Maryland corporation (&#147;Parent&#148;) and Patterson-UTI Drilling Company LP,
LLLP, a Delaware limited liability limited partnership (&#147;Buyer&#148;) and Patterson-UTI Energy, Inc., a
Delaware corporation (&#147;Patterson&#148;).


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, Key Drilling, Key Four Corners and Key Rocky Mountain are the record owners of the
Assets (defined below) being sold to the Buyer pursuant to this Agreement; and


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, Key Drilling L.P. is the beneficial owner of the Assets owned by Key Drilling being
sold to the Buyer pursuant to this Agreement; and


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, Parent directly or indirectly owns all of the equity of the Sellers; and


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, Patterson directly or indirectly owns all of the equity of Buyer; and


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, the Sellers desire to sell to Buyer, and Buyer desires to purchase from the Sellers,
the Assets.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the premises and of the mutual covenants and agreements
herein contained, the parties hereto hereby agree as follows:


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ARTICLE 1</B>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>PURCHASE AND SALE OF ASSETS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.1 <I>Purchase and Sale of the Assets</I>. Subject to the terms and conditions set forth in this
Agreement, the Sellers agree to sell, convey, transfer, assign and deliver to the Buyer the
following assets of the Sellers (all of such assets being sold hereunder are referred to
collectively herein as the &#147;Assets&#148;):


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the real property and real property leases described on <U>Schedule&nbsp;1.1(a)</U>
hereto (the &#147;Real Property&#148;);</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the tangible personal property of the Sellers (such as land drilling rigs,
drilling components, engines, machinery, spare parts, trucks, transport trailers and
equipment associated with any of the foregoing) described on <U>Schedule&nbsp;1.1(b)</U>
hereto;</TD>
</TR>

connection with the operation of the property described in <U>Section&nbsp;1.1(b)</U>;</TD>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>those contracts, contract rights, obligations and agreements of the Sellers
relating to the Assets listed on <U>Schedule&nbsp;1.1(d)</U> hereto (collectively, the
&#147;Purchased Contracts&#148;);</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.2 <I>Purchase Price. </I>As consideration for the sale of the Assets and for the other covenants
and agreements of the Sellers contained herein, the Buyer agrees to pay to the Sellers, on the
Closing Date (defined below), an aggregate purchase price of $62,000,000, subject to adjustment as
provided in <U>Section&nbsp;1.8</U> (the &#147;Purchase Price&#148;), in immediately available funds to accounts
designated by the Sellers.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.3 <I>Liabilities</I>. Effective on the Closing Date, the Buyer shall assume (i)&nbsp;those, and only
those, liabilities and obligations of the Sellers to be performed by Sellers under the Purchased
Contracts after the Closing Date; (ii)&nbsp;any liabilities or obligations asserted by any person
relating to the condition or the operation of the Assets after the Closing Date; (iii)&nbsp;any
liabilities or obligations asserted by any person after the Closing Date relating to the condition
of the Real Property (the &#147;Assumed Liabilities&#148;); <I>provided, however</I>, that the Assumed Liabilities
shall not include any liability or obligations of Sellers required to be performed after the
Closing date arising out of any breach by Sellers of the terms of the Purchased Contracts or any
defect, breach of warranty, negligence or other deficiency with respect to matters performed or
required to be performed under the Purchased Contracts on or prior to the Closing Date. The
Sellers shall be responsible for any and all liabilities and obligations of the Sellers other than
the Assumed Liabilities. All of the Sellers&#146; liabilities other than the Assumed Liabilities are
referred to herein as the &#147;Retained Liabilities&#148; and include, without limitation, (i)&nbsp;any
obligations arising on or before Closing Date from the Sellers&#146; employment of any employee,
independent contractor, consultant, agent or advisor, and any bonus (other than the Retention
Bonuses referred to below), retirement, severance, job security or similar benefit related thereto;
(ii)&nbsp;any failure to pay any Taxes (as defined in <U>Section&nbsp;2.1.3</U>) owed by the Sellers that
are applicable to the period ending with the Closing Date; and (iii)&nbsp;any liabilities or obligations
relating to the condition or the operation of the Assets on or before the Closing Date (other than
liabilities or obligations included in Assumed Liabilities pursuant to clause (iii)&nbsp;above).
Notwithstanding clause (i)&nbsp;of the preceding sentence, the Buyer shall pay the retention bonuses
(the &#147;Retention Bonuses&#148;) to those persons named on <U>Schedule&nbsp;1.3</U> who are hired by the Buyer
in the amount set forth opposite such individual&#146;s name.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.4 <I>Assumption of Risk by Buyer/Dayrates</I>. Buyer specifically assumes all risk of death,
injury, loss or damage to Buyer or any other party arising from or relating to the use, condition
or operation of the Assets after the Closing Date. Dayrates and other benefits earned as well as
costs incurred on the Purchased Contracts on or before the Closing Date (whether or not invoiced or
billed as of the Closing Date) shall be for the benefit and account of Sellers and dayrates and
other benefits earned as well as costs incurred on the Purchased Contracts after the Closing Date
shall be for the benefit and account of the Buyer; any payments or other consideration received on
the Purchased
Contracts by Sellers or Buyer shall be divided between Seller and Buyer according to these
principles.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.5 <I>Closing</I>. Consummation of the transactions contemplated by this Agreement (the &#147;Closing&#148;)
shall take place at the offices of Porter &#038; Hedges, L.L.P., 700 Louisiana Street,


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">2
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Houston, Texas
77002, within three business days after all of the conditions at closing set forth in <U>Article
4</U> have been satisfied or waived in accordance with <U>Section&nbsp;5.4</U> (the &#147;Closing Date&#148;).



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6 <I>Closing Deliveries</I>.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1 <I>Deliveries of the Seller. </I>At the Closing, in addition to the conveyance of the Assets from
the Sellers to the Buyer in exchange for the Purchase Price, the Sellers will deliver or cause to
be delivered to the Buyer:



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.1 Any assignment and bill of sale or deed necessary to effectively
transfer record and beneficial ownership of the Assets to the Buyer;



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.2 All required certificates and documents of title (other than the
Undelivered Certificates of Title (defined below)) relating to the Assets being
purchased by the Buyer duly executed and endorsed for transfer to the Buyer;



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.3 Releases of all liens to which any of the Assets were subject before
the Closing;



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.4 All written consents required to be delivered pursuant to <U>Section
2.1.9</U> or otherwise;



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.5 All other deliveries required to be delivered by the Sellers to the
Buyer pursuant to <U>Article&nbsp;4</U> here;



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.6 Evidence reasonably satisfactory to Buyer as to the termination of the
leases as required by <U>Section&nbsp;6.8</U>; and



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.1.7 All other deliveries reasonably requested by the Buyer to be delivered
by the Sellers.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.2 <I>Deliveries of the Buyer. </I>At the Closing the Buyer will deliver or cause to be delivered
to the Seller:



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.2.1 The Purchase Price;



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.2.2 All deliveries required to be delivered by the Buyer to the Sellers
pursuant to <U>Article&nbsp;4</U> of this Agreement; and



<P align="left" style="margin-left:9%; font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.6.2.3 All other deliveries reasonably requested by the Sellers to be
delivered by the Buyer.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.7 <I>Undelivered Certificates of Title</I>. The Buyer and the Sellers acknowledge that the Sellers
may be unable to deliver to the Buyer those certificates of title (the &#147;Undelivered Certificates of
Title&#148;) identified on <U>Schedule&nbsp;1.7</U> hereto. The Sellers hereby agree to deliver, or cause
to be delivered, to the Buyer, within 120&nbsp;days from the Closing Date, the Undelivered Certificates
of Title, and all lien releases, if any, in connection therewith.
